Award.AwardTitle: Nanocrystal Surface and Interfacial Free Energies on Vicinal Surfaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

This research focuses on the fundamental challenge in the study of nanostructured materials: how to determine their interfacial structure and their thermodynamic properties. A combined synthesis, characterization and modeling effort is proposed to address this challenge. Surface and interfacial properties will be measured and computed for supported nanoparticles and correlated with structure. Results are expected to have a direct impact on materials that are critical to substantial parts of technology, major components of the chemical industry, and exciting new developments in medical diagnostics. The research will be integrated with outreach efforts, including high school visits and undergraduate education. Results from this research project will be incorporated in the web-based educational materials for teaching students about structure and diffraction, infrastructure for which is already in place (see http://emaps.mrl.uiuc.edu/ or google webemaps). This particular website is now listed as one of the best web resources for learning electron diffraction.

TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

A combined experimental and theoretical study is proposed for the determination of surface and interface energies and correlation with atomic structure. Epitaxial Au nanocrystals supported on oxides will be synthesized using techniques developed in the PI's group. Aberration corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) will be used to characterize the equilibrium shapes of Au nanocrystals and as well as their interfacial structure. The structural data will be used to compute interface and step energies from first principles, which will be compared with experimental measurements based on the equilibrium shapes of supported nanocrystals. The experimental part takes the advantage of recent developments in electron microscopy, which promise imaging of oxygen atoms at the interface as well as 3D imaging of interfacial structure by depth sectioning. For theory, an energy density method will be used to compute energy distribution at surfaces and interfaces. The program builds upon the progress that has been made on Au nanocrystals supported on flat rutile (110) surfaces, and extends the study to vicinal surfaces to enable a measurement of step energies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merits: The NSF program supported a study of the surface and interfacial energies of supported metal nanoparticles and nanoparticle surface properties. Aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) was employed to examine the equilibrium shape and structure of metal nanoparticles, and in-situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was used to investigate surface properties of metal nanoparticles in the gas and liquid environment. On the theoretical front, the energy of Au on TiO2 for different interfacial structure and surface steps on TiO2 surfaces were computed from first-principles using the density functional theory energy density method (DFT-EDM). The combination of experiment with theory led to significantly improved understanding of the structure and property relationships in nanocrystal surfaces and interfaces. The major findings include:

. Triple line energy and its impact on nanocrystal equilibrium shapes

. Interaction of Gold Nanocrystals with Rutile (110) Surface Steps

. Energetics of rutile TiO2 vicinal surfaces with [001] steps

. Dynamics of Platinum Icosahedral Nanoparticle transformation

. Dissoluation Pt nanocrystal in liquids

Moreover the study enabled the development of methods and algorithms that are general and applicable for other nanostructure study. In particular, we have recently modified the computation of the DFT-EDM to treat spin-polarized systems, so that it can be applied for magnetic systems as well, and the development of environmental TEM techniques enabled the study of nanoparticle chemical reaction.

Broad impacts: The NSF supported research focused on the fundamentals of how to determine surface and interfacial energies. A combined synthesis, characterization and modeling study on the model system of Au nanocrystals supported on rutile (TiO2) was carried to address this challenge. Surface and interfacial properties were measured and computed and correlated with atomic structure. The combination of experiment with theory led to significantly improved understanding of the triple line energy and its impact on nanocrystal equilibrium shapes, nanocrystal and surface step interactions and new mechanisms about interfacial reconstruction of the reducible transition metal oxides. Results from the NSF support also contributed the writing of a book chapter on structure of nanocrystals and nanoparticles.

New methods were developed for the characterization of 3D interfacial structure based depth sectioning using aberration corrected STEM and the calculation of energy for interfacial atoms using energy density method. Applications of these methods in future are expected to broaden our understanding of materials surfaces and interfaces, whose applications spans chemistry, physics and materials engineering.

The projects directly trained 5 Ph. D students and 1 postdoc in materials science and engineering field (3 experimental and 3 in theory) at University of Illinois. These students were recruited from a pool of high qualified candidates into one of top programs in materials science and engineering. These students have now went on in diverse fields, including the role of industrial research leader and postdoctoral researcher in DOE national laboratory and Universities.

The project also helped the development of in-situ environmental TEM capability at UIUC. This capability is now a part of the facility in the Center for Microanalysis of Materials, which is used by groups within and outside UIUC for the study of chemical reactions.

This research project also supported further development of the web-based educational materials for teaching students about atomic structure and diffraction (see http://emaps.mrl.uiuc.edu/ or google webemaps). The functionalities now has been expanded to include the modelling of nanocrystals, nanodiffraction, dynamical scattering and image and diffraction pattern simulations. They are now available for download and install with extensive documentation and examples. (http://cbed.matse.illinois.edu/software_emaps.html). The EDM and Bader integration was implemented and open-source distributed (https://github.com/DallasTrinkle/BaderIntegration).
